entry.title: We All Are Ukraine üá∫üá¶
entry.summary: As a design community, we all can‚Äôt be silent in these times. We need to be united in our fight against the war, for democracy, for those dreams that children are entitled to have when they are growing up. It‚Äôs our obligation to help as much as we can. **We are donating all proceeds** from "Interface Design Checklists" PDF to support Ukraine.

entry.title: March For Equality (2022 Desktop Wallpapers Edition)
entry.summary: Following our monthly tradition, artists and designers from across the globe challenged their creative skills and designed desktop wallpapers to welcome March. They come in versions with and without a calendar and can be downloaded for free.

entry.title: A Recipe For A Good Design System
entry.summary: Maintaining a design system is a lot of work. In this article, Atila Fassina shares his lessons learned and how a platform such as Backlight can help put together a series of tools to speed up your architecture setup.

entry.summary: (This is a sponsored post.) In recent years, the Jamstack methodology for building websites has become increasingly popular. entry.title: How To Benchmark And Improve Web Vitals With Real User Metrics
entry.summary: Web Vitals are the new gold standard in performance due to their direct correlation with the user‚Äôs experience. In this article, you‚Äôll learn what monitoring can do and how RayGun can help you sustain performance maintenance while scaling your app.

Plus, CSS can request other files, and ‚Ä¶ CSS Database Queries? Sure We Can! originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.

entry.title: Using The WordPress Editor And CPTs To Configure Plugins
entry.summary: If we want our WordPress plugins to offer a settings page that is fully powered by blocks, how can we do it? Since *Full Site Editing* doesn‚Äôt support this feature yet, we need to code a custom solution. In this article, we will learn how we can do it.

entry.title: How To Develop A Text Editor For The Web
entry.summary: How do text typing and editing work on the web? Although this process might seem straightforward, there is a lot of technical nuance behind its apparent simplicity. This article looks at how typing on the web works.

entry.title: Smashing Podcast Episode 45 With Jeremy Wagner: What Is Responsible JavaScript?
entry.summary: In this episode, we‚Äôre talking about Responsible JavaScript. What does it mean for code to be responsible, and how should we approach projects differently? Drew McLellan talks to expert Jeremy Wagner to find out.

entry.title: Testing Pipeline 101 For Frontend Testing
entry.summary: You don‚Äôt need to be a full DevOps engineer if you want to introduce a testing build routine. With the help of some testing frameworks and GitHub actions, Ramona Schwering gives a short kick-off to help you get on the right track.

entry.title: Thoughts On Markdown
entry.summary: Markdown in all its flavors, interpretations, and forks won‚Äôt go away. However, it‚Äôs important to look at emerging content formats that try to encompass modern needs. In this article, Knut shares his advice against Markdown by looking back on why it was introduced in the first place, and by going through some of the major developments of content on the web.

entry.title: Falling In Love With The Web: Inspiring Websites And Tools
entry.summary: We all need a little inspiration boost every now and again. In this post, we collected inspiring resources from all across the web for you ‚Äî beautiful eye candy, tips to challenge your skills, and useful tools that are bound to spark new ideas. Enjoy!

entry.title: Implications Of WordPress Joining The Block Protocol
entry.summary: In this article, Leonardo Losoviz discusses some potential consequences as well as positive outcomes of WordPress joining the Block Protocol.

entry.title: Everything You Want To Know About Creating Voice User Interfaces
entry.summary: Voice is a powerful tool that we can use to communicate with each other. This article covers the most critical aspects of designing for voice user interfaces: designing the conversation and designing visual interfaces.

entry.title: Web Design Done Well: Perfectly Pointless
entry.summary: This installment of *Web Design Done Well* celebrates weird and wacky websites. Sites with sweet, innocent, sometimes pointless purposes. Are they money makers? Game changers? Not necessarily, but they sure are fun, and in ways only the web could really manage.

entry.title: Fitts‚Äô Law In The Touch Era
entry.summary: In this article, Steven Hoober shines the spotlight on Fitts‚Äô Law and explains why we should always ask questions and consider what particular guidelines and lessons mean to our users and our products.

entry.title: Statoscope: A Course Of Intensive Therapy For Your Bundle
entry.summary: Statoscope is an instrument that analyses your webpack-bundles. Created by Sergey Melukov, it started out as an experimental version in late 2016, which has now become a full-fledged toolkit for viewing, analyzing, and validating webpack-bundles.

entry.title: Using QR Codes In Your Business: Best Practices And Pitfalls
entry.summary: While QR codes have many uses and can be leveraged at many touch points, they are just one of dozens of technologies that can improve the customer‚Äôs journey. Stanislav Khrustalev shares his advice with a list of things to keep in mind when using QR codes for your business.

entry.title: What Web Frameworks Solve: The Vanilla Alternative (Part 2)
entry.summary: In this second part, Noam suggests a few patterns of how to use the web platform directly as an alternative to some of the solutions that are offered by frameworks.

entry.title: Reducing The Web‚Äôs Carbon Footprint: Optimizing Social Media Embeds
entry.summary: In this article, we‚Äôll look specifically at what we can do to reduce the impact of social media embeds and social sharing widgets ‚Äî or even some strategies to avoid them altogether. While the spotlight is on reducing the environmental impact, many of these tips will be great for performance too.
